1124310.1007/11243.1572-901XTransition Metal ChemistryTransit Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer International PublishingChams11243-017-0157-515710.1007/s11243-017-0157-5ArticleSynthesis, crystal structures and photochromic properties of two coordination polymers based on a rigid tetracarboxylic acid ligandLiuJian-Jun1aLiuTeng1XiaShu-Biao1ChengFei-Xiang1HuangChang-Cang20000 0004 1762 8988grid.452648.9Center for Yunnan-Guizhou Plateau Chemical Functional Materials and Pollution ControlQujing Normal University655011QujingChina0000 0001 0130 6528grid.411604.6College of chemistryFuzhou University350116FuzhouChinajianjun_liu@mail.qjnu.edu.cn1372017920174265255312162017114201720620171372017© Springer International Publishing AG 20172017Abstract

Manganese(II) and nickel(II) coordination polymers, [Mn(L)(H2O)2]n (1) and [Ni(L)·14H2O]n (2), have been synthesized from a rigid viologen-based tetracarboxylic acid ligand, 1,1′-bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium dichloride (H4L·2Cl) and the Mn(II)/Ni(II) chlorides. The compounds have been characterized by infrared spectra, elemental analyses, single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction analyses and thermogravimetric analyses. Compound 1 has a 2D coordination network with uncoordinated carboxyl groups, which further stack into a 3D supramolecular structure by hydrogen-bonding interactions. Compound 2 shows a 3D supramolecular framework with 1D channels along the crystallographic b-axis, formed from zigzag chains through hydrogen-bonding interactions. Both compounds display prominent photochromic and photomagnetic behavior upon light irradiation, suggesting that they may be potential photomagnetic materials.

Introduction

Chromic materials have interesting potential applications in fields such as chemistry, physics, biology and materials science [1–3]. They can be divided into various categories according to the external stimuli, specifically thermochromic [4], photochromic [5], mechano-/piezochromic [6] and electrochromic materials [7]. Among these chromic materials, there is much current interest in photochromic materials owing to their possible applications in fields such as protection, decoration, displays, memory, switches, photography and sensors [8–10]. To the best of our knowledge, the research in this domain has mainly concentrated on pure organic photochromic materials, such as spirooxazines, N-salicylidenes and Schiff bases, but there are rare examples of electron-transfer complexes [11–13].

The key to design and syntheses of such electron-transfer photochromic complexes is to choose suitable electron donors and acceptors. N,N′-disubstituted 4,4′-bipyridiniums (viologens) are an attractive class of electron acceptor molecules containing an electrically charged moiety within the conjugated system and have been adopted to prepare redox photochromic materials [14, 15]. Many groups have put most of their efforts into investigating the influence of the surroundings of bipyridinium derivatives on the photochromism, such as different substituents and coexisting guest species [16–18]. Some zwitterionic viologen derivatives bearing carboxylate as a coordinating group have been used to construct coordination polymers, most of which contain a variety of secondary ligands as counterions [19–22]. Recently, Gao’s group have reported on coordination polymers based on a viologen ligand, which possess interesting magnetic and electrochemical properties [23, 24]. Considering that some flexible viologen-based di- and tetracarboxylic ligands have been used to synthesize coordination compounds [14, 25], the coordination chemistry of rigid viologen ligands is nevertheless still relatively unexplored. In this paper, we report the syntheses and crystal structures of two new coordination polymers, namely [Mn(L)(H2O)2]n (1) and [Ni(L)(H2O)4·14H2O]n (2), which are both photochromic electron-transfer complexes, derived from the rigid viologen-based tetracarboxylic ligand 1,1′-bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium dichloride (H4L·2Cl).

ExperimentalMaterials and methods

All reagents and solvents for synthesis were commercially available and used directly without further purification. 1,1′-Bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium dichloride (H4L·2Cl) was synthesized according to the procedure reported in the literature [23]. IR spectra were recorded in the range 4000–400 cm−1 on a Perkin-Elmer FTIR spectrum 2000 spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were measured on an Elementar Vario EL III microanalyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku MiniFlex-II X-Ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). TGA measurements were performed on a TG-209 system with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an N2 atmosphere. UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra were measured at room temperature on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda-950 UV–Vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. Electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements were recorded on a Bruker A300 spectrometer operating in the X-band at room temperature. Magnetic susceptibility data were collected over the temperature range of 2–300 K in a magnetic field of 1000 Oe with an MPMS (SQUID)-XL magnetometer.

Synthesis of compound <bold>1</bold>

[H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and MnCl2·4H2O (0.020 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL), and the mixture was stirred for 10 min. Then, dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 72 h in a sealed glass bottle. The yellow crystals were separated by filtration, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 68%. Anal. Calcd for C26H18MnN2O10: C, 54.41; N, 4.88; H, 3.14. Found, C, 54.32; N, 4.54; H, 3.08. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3472(br), 3113(w), 3010(m), 1671(m), 1619(s), 1562(s), 1536(m), 1395(s), 1338(s), 1173(m), 1068(m), 923(m), 757(m), 689(s), 507(m).

Synthesis of compound <bold>2</bold>

[H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and NiCl2·6H2O (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL) and stirred for 10 min. Dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was then added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 48 h in a sealed glass bottle. The light yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 73%. Anal. Calcd for C26H50N2NiO26: C, 36.05; N, 3.24; H, 5.78. Found, C, 36.23; N, 3.32; H, 5.65. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3229(br), 3110(w), 3060(w), 1648(m), 1613(s), 1550(s), 1471(m), 1347(s), 1211(s), 1073(m), 826(m), 727(s), 582(m).

Crystal structure determinations

Suitable single crystals of both compounds were mounted on glass fibers for the X-ray measurements. Diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku-AFC7 diffractometer equipped with a Rigaku Saturn CCD area-detector system. The measurements were made with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 153 K under a cold nitrogen stream. The frame data were integrated and absorption corrections made using the Rigaku CrystalClear program package. All calculations were performed with the SHELXTL-97 program package, and structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares against F2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the water were located in the difference Fourier map and the position refined with the O–H distance restrained to 0.85(1) Å. For compound 1, the diffraction data were treated by the “SQUEEZE” method as implemented in PLATON to remove diffuse electron density associated with badly disordered solvent molecules. Due to the mixed solvents that were used during the synthesis of compound 1, the solvent content could not be precisely specified. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication numbers CCDC 1539486 and 1539487 for 1 and 2, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif (Tables 1, 2).

Results and discussionCrystal structure of compound <bold>1</bold>

Single-crystal X-ray structure analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and exhibits a 2D coordination network. The asymmetric unit contains one Mn(II) center, one L ligand and two coordinated water ligands. It should be pointed out that several solvent molecules were detected, but most of them were largely disordered, and could not be located in the crystal structural refinement. Accordingly, all of the solvent contribution was subtracted from the data using SQUEEZE during the refinement [26]. As shown in Fig. 1a, the Mn(II) center is six-coordinated by two water ligands and four oxygen atoms from four independent L ligands in monodentate modes, giving a distorted octahedral geometry (Fig. 1a). The Mn–O distances are 2.152(2)–2.223(19) Å, which are comparable with previously reported data [27]. Meanwhile, each ligand L connects three Mn(II) centers through its three hydroxy groups, while each Mn(II) connects with four L ligands through O atoms. This gives rise to a 2D framework as shown in Fig. 1b, which further stacks into a 3D supramolecular network through O–H···O hydrogen bonds (dO–O = 2.698 Å) between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the L ligands (Fig. 1c). In the 2D framework, pairs of Mn atoms are doubly bridged by two carboxyl groups from two L ligands to form a dinuclear unit with Mn···Mn distance of 3.500 Å.

Crystal structure of compound <bold>2</bold>

Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and exhibits a 1D coordination network. The asymmetric unit contains one Ni(II) center, one L ligand, four coordinated water ligands and fourteen free water molecules. As shown in Fig. 2a, the Ni(II) center is six-coordinated by four water ligands plus two oxygen atoms from two independent L ligands in monodentate modes, giving a distorted octahedral geometry (Fig. 2a). The Ni–O distances are 2.026(4)–2.084(19) Å, which are comparable with previously reported data [28]. In compound 2, the deprotonated L ligands bridge two Ni atoms, each of which is bridged by two L ligands, extending the structure into a zigzag chain (Fig. 2b). The neighboring two zigzag chains are interconnected through hydrogen bonds between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO–O = 2.687–2.719 Å), to generate a 2D supramolecular network (Fig. 2c). This is connected into three dimensions by another hydrogen bond interaction between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO–O = 2.692 Å, Fig. 2d). The 1D channels along the crystallographic b-axis are filled by free water molecules; the pore size is ca. 9.6 × 11.5 Å2 (Fig. 2d, taking into account of the van der Waals radii, measured as the largest and shortest distances between the diagonals of the parallelogram). The PLATON calculations show that the guest accessible volume (1710.2 Å3 per unit cell) comprises 42.7% of the unit cell volume [26].

Thermogravimetric analyses

The thermogravimetric analyses were performed under an N2 atmosphere on crystalline samples of both compounds (Figure S3-S4). For compound 1, the first weight loss occurred at 50–110 °C, corresponding to loss of the free solvent molecules (calc. 12.8%, obs. 12.5%). The next weight loss occurred (calc. 4.8%, obs. 4.6%) from 110 to 200 °C, which could be attributed to the loss of two coordinated water ligands. Above ca. 300 °C, compound 1 started to lose its ligand L as a result of thermal decomposition. In compound 2, the loss of the free water molecules (calc. 28.9%, obs. 28.5%) occurred from 30 to 145 °C. The next process occurred at 145–200 °C with a weight loss of 8.3% (calc. 8.5%), corresponding to loss of four coordinated water ligands. Then above ca. 300 °C, compound 2 started to decompose.

Photochromic properties

Both compounds show color changes upon illumination with a 300 W Xe lamp (Fig. 3). The yellow samples of both compounds turn dark green or green after illumination. The green photoproducts are stable in air without any noticeable color change for two days, but the color slowly changes back to yellow upon prolonged standing in air. In addition, such decolored samples also display color changes after further irradiation, indicating reversible photochromism for both compounds. The UV–Vis reflectance spectra were measured before and after illumination. The original spectra both show strong absorption bands below 400 nm, with rapidly decreased tailing in the visible light region, assigned to the n–π* and π–π* transitions of the conjugated aromatic carboxylate. The photoproducts of both compounds show new characteristic bands at 520 and 690 nm. These bands are similar to those observed for the bipyridinium radical [29, 30], suggesting that the color change of may arise from the photoinduced generation of radicals in the ligand L. Their coloration tends to be saturated after illumination for 30 min, as the UV–Vis spectra show no further change, indicating that the photochromic process has gone to completion.

To confirm the generation of the radicals, the electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra of both compounds were measured before and after irradiation (Fig. 4). The ESR spectrum of the virgin sample 1 is broad, which is typical of a normal Mn(II) complex [23, 31]. However, a signal was observed at g = 2.0023, which is uncertain whether the signal has a contribution from residual radicals. After irradiation, the signal at g = 2.0023 is dramatically increased in intensity, confirming the formation of radicals (Fig. 4a). For compound 2, no organic radical signals were detected before irradiation [32]; however, after light irradiation, a noticeable signal with a g value of 2.0042 was observed, suggesting the generation of viologen radicals (Fig. 4b). It is generally known that viologen derivatives are redox active and can generate radicals upon light irradiation. The PXRD and IR spectra of these compounds show no obvious changes during the photochromic process, suggesting that the crystal structure remains intact (Figure S1-S2 and S5-S6). Thus, the photochromic process may be attributed to photoinduced radical generation within the viologen ligand.

Magnetic properties

Magnetic studies have been performed on powdered crystalline samples of both compounds before and after irradiation. The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 1–2 were investigated in the range of 2–300 K with a 1 kOe applied field (Fig. 5). The χMT of 1 at 300 K before irradiation is 4.11 cm3 K mol−1, which is slightly lower than the value for one magnetically non-interacting Mn2+ ion with S = 5/2 and g = 2 (χMT = 4.375 cm3 K mol−1). With decreasing temperature, the χMT value increases and reaches 7.38 cm3 K mol−1 at 2.0 K. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility in the temperature range 2-300 K is well fitted by the Curie–Weiss law with C = 3.92 cm3 K mol−1 and θ = 8.10 K (Figure S7), indicating ferromagnetic coupling between the Mn centers. After illumination with Xe light for 30 min, the χMT value at 300 K fell by 11.4%. This reduction is larger than that previously reported by Iversen et al. [33].

For compound 2, the value of χMT at 300 K is 1.37 cm3 K mol−1, as expected for the spin-only value of one Ni2+ with S = 1 and g = 2.31. As the temperature decreases, the χMT value remains almost constant down to about 50 K and then starts to increase rapidly, reaching 3.05 cm3 K mol−1 at 14 K, after which it drops abruptly to a minimum value of 1.28 cm3 K mol−1 at 2 K. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities obeys the Curie–Weiss law above 5 K with C = 1.40 cm3 K mol−1 and θ = 8.53 K (Figure S8), consistent with ferromagnetic coupling between the Ni2+ centers. After illumination with Xe light for 30 min, the χMT value at 300 K fell by 10.5%. The observed decreases in χMT at 300 K for both compounds after illumination may be attributed to the strong interaction between the viologen radical and the metal ions (Mn2+/Ni2+). The magnetic behavior will require more detailed study in the future.

Conclusion

In conclusion, two new coordination polymers were solvothermally synthesized by using a rigid viologen-based ligand. Both compounds display prominent photochromic and photomagnetic behavior upon light irradiation. Hence, this work demonstrates a new strategy for the design of molecular photomagnetic materials.

Considering that some flexible viologen-based di- and tetracarboxylic ligands have been used to synthesize coordination compounds [14, 25], the coordination chemistry of rigid viologen ligands is nevertheless still relatively unexplored. In this paper, we report the syntheses and crystal structures of two new coordination polymers, namely [Mn(L)(H2O)2]n (1) and [Ni(L)(H2O)4⋅14H2O]n (2), which are both photochromic electron-transfer complexes, derived from the rigid viologen-based tetracarboxylic ligand 1,1'-bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium dichloride (H4L⋅2Cl).ExperimentalMaterials and methodsAll reagents and solvents for synthesis were commercially available and used directly without further purification. 1,1'-Bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium dichloride (H4L⋅2Cl) was synthesized according to the procedure reported in the literature [23]. IR spectra were recorded in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on a Perkin-Elmer FTIR spectrum 2000 spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were measured on an Elementar Vario EL III microanalyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku MiniFlex-II X-Ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). TGA measurements were performed on a TG-209 system with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an N2 atmosphere. UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra were measured at room temperature on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda-950 UV-Vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. Electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements were recorded on a Bruker A300 spectrometer operating in the X-band at room temperature. Magnetic susceptibility data were collected over the temperature range of 2-300 K in a magnetic field of 1000 Oe with an MPMS (SQUID)-XL magnetometer.Synthesis of compound 1[H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and MnCl2⋅4H2O (0.020 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL), and the mixture was stirred for 10 min. Then, dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 72 h in a sealed glass bottle. The yellow crystals were separated by filtration, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 68%. Anal. Calcd for C26H18MnN2O10: C, 54.41; N, 4.88; H, 3.14. Found, C, 54.32; N, 4.54; H, 3.08. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3472(br), 3113(w), 3010(m), 1671(m), 1619(s), 1562(s), 1536(m), 1395(s), 1338(s), 1173(m), 1068(m), 923(m), 757(m), 689(s), 507(m).Synthesis of compound 2[H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and NiCl2⋅6H2O (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL) and stirred for 10 min. Dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was then added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 48 h in a sealed glass bottle. The light yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 73%. Anal. Calcd for C26H50N2NiO26: C, 36.05; N, 3.24; H, 5.78. Found, C, 36.23; N, 3.32; H, 5.65. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3229(br), 3110(w), 3060(w), 1648(m), 1613(s), 1550(s), 1471(m), 1347(s), 1211(s), 1073(m), 826(m), 727(s), 582(m).Crystal structure determinationsSuitable single crystals of both compounds were mounted on glass fibers for the X-ray measurements. Diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku-AFC7 diffractometer equipped with a Rigaku Saturn CCD area-detector system. The measurements were made with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 153 K under a cold nitrogen stream. The frame data were integrated and absorption corrections made using the Rigaku CrystalClear program package. All calculations were performed with the SHELXTL-97 program package, and structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares against F2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the water were located in the difference Fourier map and the position refined with the O-H distance restrained to 0.85(1) Å. For compound 1, the diffraction data were treated by the "SQUEEZE" method as implemented in PLATON to remove diffuse electron density associated with badly disordered solvent molecules. Due to the mixed solvents that were used during the synthesis of compound 1, the solvent content could not be precisely specified. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication numbers CCDC 1539486 and 1539487 for 1 and 2, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif (Tables 1, 2).Results and discussionCrystal structure of compound 1Single-crystal X-ray structure analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and exhibits a 2D coordination network. The asymmetric unit contains one Mn(II) center, one L ligand and two coordinated water ligands. It should be pointed out that several solvent molecules were detected, but most of them were largely disordered, and could not be located in the crystal structural refinement. Accordingly, all of the solvent contribution was subtracted from the data using SQUEEZE during the refinement [26]. As shown in Fig. 1a, the Mn(II) center is six-coordinated by two water ligands and four oxygen atoms from four independent L ligands in monodentate modes, giving a distorted octahedral geometry (Fig. 1a). The Mn-O distances are 2.152(2)-2.223(19) Å, which are comparable with previously reported data [27]. Meanwhile, each ligand L connects three Mn(II) centers through its three hydroxy groups, while each Mn(II) connects with four L ligands through O atoms. This gives rise to a 2D framework as shown in Fig. 1b, which further stacks into a 3D supramolecular network through O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (dO-O = 2.698 Å) between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the L ligands (Fig. 1c). In the 2D framework, pairs of Mn atoms are doubly bridged by two carboxyl groups from two L ligands to form a dinuclear unit with Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance of 3.500 Å.Crystal structure of compound 2Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and exhibits a 1D coordination network. The asymmetric unit contains one Ni(II) center, one L ligand, four coordinated water ligands and fourteen free water molecules. As shown in Fig. 2a, the Ni(II) center is six-coordinated by four water ligands plus two oxygen atoms from two independent L ligands in monodentate modes, giving a distorted octahedral geometry (Fig. 2a). The Ni-O distances are 2.026(4)-2.084(19) Å, which are comparable with previously reported data [28]. In compound 2, the deprotonated L ligands bridge two Ni atoms, each of which is bridged by two L ligands, extending the structure into a zigzag chain (Fig. 2b). The neighboring two zigzag chains are interconnected through hydrogen bonds between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO-O = 2.687-2.719 Å), to generate a 2D supramolecular network (Fig. 2c). This is connected into three dimensions by another hydrogen bond interaction between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO-O = 2.692 Å, Fig. 2d). The 1D channels along the crystallographic b-axis are filled by free water molecules; the pore size is ca. 9.6 × 11.5 Å2 (Fig. 2d, taking into account of the van der Waals radii, measured as the largest and shortest distances between the diagonals of the parallelogram). The PLATON calculations show that the guest accessible volume (1710.2 Å3 per unit cell) comprises 42.7% of the unit cell volume [26].Thermogravimetric analysesThe thermogravimetric analyses were performed under an N2 atmosphere on crystalline samples of both compounds (Figure S3-S4). For compound 1, the first weight loss occurred at 50-110 °C, corresponding to loss of the free solvent molecules (calc. 12.8%, obs. 12.5%). The next weight loss occurred (calc. 4.8%, obs. 4.6%) from 110 to 200 °C, which could be attributed to the loss of two coordinated water ligands. Above ca. 300 °C, compound 1 started to lose its ligand L as a result of thermal decomposition. In compound 2, the loss of the free water molecules (calc. 28.9%, obs. 28.5%) occurred from 30 to 145 °C. The next process occurred at 145-200 °C with a weight loss of 8.3% (calc. 8.5%), corresponding to loss of four coordinated water ligands. Then above ca. 300 °C, compound 2 started to decompose.Photochromic propertiesBoth compounds show color changes upon illumination with a 300 W Xe lamp (Fig. 3). The yellow samples of both compounds turn dark green or green after illumination. The green photoproducts are stable in air without any noticeable color change for two days, but the color slowly changes back to yellow upon prolonged standing in air. In addition, such decolored samples also display color changes after further irradiation, indicating reversible photochromism for both compounds. The UV-Vis reflectance spectra were measured before and after illumination. The original spectra both show strong absorption bands below 400 nm, with rapidly decreased tailing in the visible light region, assigned to the n-π* and π-π* transitions of the conjugated aromatic carboxylate. The photoproducts of both compounds show new characteristic bands at 520 and 690 nm. These bands are similar to those observed for the bipyridinium radical [29, 30], suggesting that the color change of may arise from the photoinduced generation of radicals in the ligand L. Their coloration tends to be saturated after illumination for 30 min, as the UV-Vis spectra show no further change, indicating that the photochromic process has gone to completion.To confirm the generation of the radicals, the electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra of both compounds were measured before and after irradiation (Fig. 4). The ESR spectrum of the virgin sample 1 is broad, which is typical of a normal Mn(II) complex [23, 31]. However, a signal was observed at g = 2.0023, which is uncertain whether the signal has a contribution from residual radicals. After irradiation, the signal at g = 2.0023 is dramatically increased in intensity, confirming the formation of radicals (Fig. 4a). For compound 2, no organic radical signals were detected before irradiation [32]; however, after light irradiation, a noticeable signal with a g value of 2.0042 was observed, suggesting the generation of viologen radicals (Fig. 4b). It is generally known that viologen derivatives are redox active and can generate radicals upon light irradiation. The PXRD and IR spectra of these compounds show no obvious changes during the photochromic process, suggesting that the crystal structure remains intact (Figure S1-S2 and S5-S6). Thus, the photochromic process may be attributed to photoinduced radical generation within the viologen ligand.Magnetic propertiesMagnetic studies have been performed on powdered crystalline samples of both compounds before and after irradiation. The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 1-2 were investigated in the range of 2-300 K with a 1 kOe applied field (Fig. 5). The χMT of 1 at 300 K before irradiation is 4.11 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly lower than the value for one magnetically non-interacting Mn2+ ion with S = 5/2 and g = 2 (χMT = 4.375 cm3 K mol-1). With decreasing temperature, the χMT value increases and reaches 7.38 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility in the temperature range 2-300 K is well fitted by the Curie-Weiss law with C = 3.92 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = 8.10 K (Figure S7), indicating ferromagnetic coupling between the Mn centers. After illumination with Xe light for 30 min, the χMT value at 300 K fell by 11.4%. This reduction is larger than that previously reported by Iversen et al. [33].For compound 2, the value of χMT at 300 K is 1.37 cm3 K mol-1, as expected for the spin-only value of one Ni2+ with S = 1 and g = 2.31. As the temperature decreases, the χMT value remains almost constant down to about 50 K and then starts to increase rapidly, reaching 3.05 cm3 K mol-1 at 14 K, after which it drops abruptly to a minimum value of 1.28 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities obeys the Curie-Weiss law above 5 K with C = 1.40 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = 8.53 K (Figure S8), consistent with ferromagnetic coupling between the Ni2+ centers. After illumination with Xe light for 30 min, the χMT value at 300 K fell by 10.5%. The observed decreases in χMT at 300 K for both compounds after illumination may be attributed to the strong interaction between the viologen radical and the metal ions (Mn2+/Ni2+). The magnetic behavior will require more detailed study in the future.ConclusionIn conclusion, two new coordination polymers were solvothermally synthesized by using a rigid viologen-based ligand. Both compounds display prominent photochromic and photomagnetic behavior upon light irradiation. Hence, this work demonstrates a new strategy for the design of molecular photomagnetic materials.AcknowledegmentsWe thank for the financial supports from the National Natural Science Foundation of The compounds have been characterized by infrared spectra, elemental analyses, single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction analyses and thermogravimetric analyses. Compound 1 has a 2D coordination network with uncoordinated carboxyl groups, which further stack into a 3D supramolecular structure by hydrogen-bonding interactions. Compound 2 shows a 3D supramolecular framework with 1D channels along the crystallographic b-axis, formed from zigzag chains through hydrogen-bonding interactions. Both compounds display prominent photochromic and photomagnetic behavior upon light irradiation, suggesting that they may be potential photomagnetic materials.

Abstract

Manganese(II) and nickel(II) coordination polymers, [Mn(L)(H2O)2]n (1) and [Ni(L)⋅14H2O]n (2), have been synthesized from a rigid viologen-based tetracarboxylic acid ligand, 1,1'-bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium dichloride (H4L⋅2Cl) and the Mn(II)/Ni(II) chlorides. The compounds have been characterized by infrared spectra, elemental analyses, single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction analyses and thermogravimetric analyses. Compound 1 has a 2D coordination network with uncoordinated carboxyl groups, which further stack into a 3D supramolecular structure by hydrogen-bonding interactions. Compound 2 shows a 3D supramolecular framework with 1D channels along the crystallographic b-axis, formed from zigzag chains through hydrogen-bonding interactions. Both compounds display prominent photochromic and photomagnetic behavior upon light irradiation, suggesting that they may be potential photomagnetic materials.

elements.content: Chromic materials have interesting potential applications in fields such as chemistry, physics, biology and materials science [1–3]. They can be divided into various categories according to the external stimuli, specifically thermochromic [4], photochromic [5], mechano-/piezochromic [6] and electrochromic materials [7]. Among these chromic materials, there is much current interest in photochromic materials owing to their possible applications in fields such as protection, decoration, displays, memory, switches, photography and sensors [8–10]. To the best of our knowledge, the research in this domain has mainly concentrated on pure organic photochromic materials, such as spirooxazines, N-salicylidenes and Schiff bases, but there are rare examples of electron-transfer complexes [11–13].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Chromic materials have interesting potential applications in fields such as chemistry, physics, biology and materials science [1-3]. They can be divided into various categories according to the external stimuli, specifically thermochromic [4], photochromic [5], mechano-/piezochromic [6] and electrochromic materials [7]. Among these chromic materials, there is much current interest in photochromic materials owing to their possible applications in fields such as protection, decoration, displays, memory, switches, photography and sensors [8-10]. To the best of our knowledge, the research in this domain has mainly concentrated on pure organic photochromic materials, such as spirooxazines, N-salicylidenes and Schiff bases, but there are rare examples of electron-transfer complexes [11-13].

elements.content: The key to design and syntheses of such electron-transfer photochromic complexes is to choose suitable electron donors and acceptors. N,N′-disubstituted 4,4′-bipyridiniums (viologens) are an attractive class of electron acceptor molecules containing an electrically charged moiety within the conjugated system and have been adopted to prepare redox photochromic materials [14, 15]. Many groups have put most of their efforts into investigating the influence of the surroundings of bipyridinium derivatives on the photochromism, such as different substituents and coexisting guest species [16–18]. Some zwitterionic viologen derivatives bearing carboxylate as a coordinating group have been used to construct coordination polymers, most of which contain a variety of secondary ligands as counterions [19–22]. Recently, Gao’s group have reported on coordination polymers based on a viologen ligand, which possess interesting magnetic and electrochemical properties [23, 24]. Considering that some flexible viologen-based di- and tetracarboxylic ligands have been used to synthesize coordination compounds [14, 25], the coordination chemistry of rigid viologen ligands is nevertheless still relatively unexplored. In this paper, we report the syntheses and crystal structures of two new coordination polymers, namely [Mn(L)(H2O)2]n (1) and [Ni(L)(H2O)4·14H2O]n (2), which are both photochromic electron-transfer complexes, derived from the rigid viologen-based tetracarboxylic ligand 1,1′-bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium dichloride (H4L·2Cl).

Experimental

Materials and methods

All reagents and solvents for synthesis were commercially available and used directly without further purification. 1,1'-Bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium dichloride (H4L⋅2Cl) was synthesized according to the procedure reported in the literature [23]. IR spectra were recorded in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on a Perkin-Elmer FTIR spectrum 2000 spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were measured on an Elementar Vario EL III microanalyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku MiniFlex-II X-Ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å). TGA measurements were performed on a TG-209 system with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an N2 atmosphere. UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra were measured at room temperature on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda-950 UV-Vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. Electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements were recorded on a Bruker A300 spectrometer operating in the X-band at room temperature. Magnetic susceptibility data were collected over the temperature range of 2-300 K in a magnetic field of 1000 Oe with an MPMS (SQUID)-XL magnetometer.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of compound 1

[H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and MnCl2⋅4H2O (0.020 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL), and the mixture was stirred for 10 min. Then, dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 72 h in a sealed glass bottle. The yellow crystals were separated by filtration, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 68%. Anal. Calcd for C26H18MnN2O10: C, 54.41; N, 4.88; H, 3.14. Found, C, 54.32; N, 4.54; H, 3.08. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3472(br), 3113(w), 3010(m), 1671(m), 1619(s), 1562(s), 1536(m), 1395(s), 1338(s), 1173(m), 1068(m), 923(m), 757(m), 689(s), 507(m).

elements.content: [H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and NiCl2·6H2O (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL) and stirred for 10 min. Dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was then added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 48 h in a sealed glass bottle. The light yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 73%. Anal. Calcd for C26H50N2NiO26: C, 36.05; N, 3.24; H, 5.78. Found, C, 36.23; N, 3.32; H, 5.65. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3229(br), 3110(w), 3060(w), 1648(m), 1613(s), 1550(s), 1471(m), 1347(s), 1211(s), 1073(m), 826(m), 727(s), 582(m).

Synthesis of compound 2

[H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and NiCl2⋅6H2O (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL) and stirred for 10 min. Dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was then added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 48 h in a sealed glass bottle. The light yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 73%. Anal. Calcd for C26H50N2NiO26: C, 36.05; N, 3.24; H, 5.78. Found, C, 36.23; N, 3.32; H, 5.65. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3229(br), 3110(w), 3060(w), 1648(m), 1613(s), 1550(s), 1471(m), 1347(s), 1211(s), 1073(m), 826(m), 727(s), 582(m).

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of both compounds were mounted on glass fibers for the X-ray measurements. Diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku-AFC7 diffractometer equipped with a Rigaku Saturn CCD area-detector system. The measurements were made with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 153 K under a cold nitrogen stream. The frame data were integrated and absorption corrections made using the Rigaku CrystalClear program package. All calculations were performed with the SHELXTL-97 program package, and structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares against F2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the water were located in the difference Fourier map and the position refined with the O–H distance restrained to 0.85(1) Å. For compound 1, the diffraction data were treated by the “SQUEEZE” method as implemented in PLATON to remove diffuse electron density associated with badly disordered solvent molecules. Due to the mixed solvents that were used during the synthesis of compound 1, the solvent content could not be precisely specified. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication numbers CCDC 1539486 and 1539487 for 1 and 2, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif (Tables 1, 2).

Diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku-AFC7 diffractometer equipped with a Rigaku Saturn CCD area-detector system. The measurements were made with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 153 K under a cold nitrogen stream. The frame data were integrated and absorption corrections made using the Rigaku CrystalClear program package. All calculations were performed with the SHELXTL-97 program package, and structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares against F2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the water were located in the difference Fourier map and the position refined with the O-H distance restrained to 0.85(1) Å. For compound 1, the diffraction data were treated by the "SQUEEZE" method as implemented in PLATON to remove diffuse electron density associated with badly disordered solvent molecules. Due to the mixed solvents that were used during the synthesis of compound 1, the solvent content could not be precisely specified. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication numbers CCDC 1539486 and 1539487 for 1 and 2, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif (Tables 1, 2).

Single-crystal X-ray structure analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and exhibits a 2D coordination network. The asymmetric unit contains one Mn(II) center, one L ligand and two coordinated water ligands. It should be pointed out that several solvent molecules were detected, but most of them were largely disordered, and could not be located in the crystal structural refinement. Accordingly, all of the solvent contribution was subtracted from the data using SQUEEZE during the refinement [26]. As shown in Fig. 1a, the Mn(II) center is six-coordinated by two water ligands and four oxygen atoms from four independent L ligands in monodentate modes, giving a distorted octahedral geometry (Fig. 1a). The Mn–O distances are 2.152(2)–2.223(19) Å, which are comparable with previously reported data [27]. Meanwhile, each ligand L connects three Mn(II) centers through its three hydroxy groups, while each Mn(II) connects with four L ligands through O atoms. This gives rise to a 2D framework as shown in Fig. 1b, which further stacks into a 3D supramolecular network through O–H···O hydrogen bonds (dO–O = 2.698 Å) between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the L ligands (Fig. 1c). In the 2D framework, pairs of Mn atoms are doubly bridged by two carboxyl groups from two L ligands to form a dinuclear unit with Mn···Mn distance of 3.500 Å.

Results and discussion

Crystal structure of compound 1

Single-crystal X-ray structure analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and exhibits a 2D coordination network. The asymmetric unit contains one Mn(II) center, one L ligand and two coordinated water ligands. It should be pointed out that several solvent molecules were detected, but most of them were largely disordered, and could not be located in the crystal structural refinement. Accordingly, all of the solvent contribution was subtracted from the data using SQUEEZE during the refinement [26]. As shown in Fig. 1a, the Mn(II) center is six-coordinated by two water ligands and four oxygen atoms from four independent L ligands in monodentate modes, giving a distorted octahedral geometry (Fig. 1a). The Mn-O distances are 2.152(2)-2.223(19) Å, which are comparable with previously reported data [27]. Meanwhile, each ligand L connects three Mn(II) centers through its three hydroxy groups, while each Mn(II) connects with four L ligands through O atoms. This gives rise to a 2D framework as shown in Fig. 1b, which further stacks into a 3D supramolecular network through O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (dO-O = 2.698 Å) between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the L ligands (Fig. 1c). In the 2D framework, pairs of Mn atoms are doubly bridged by two carboxyl groups from two L ligands to form a dinuclear unit with Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance of 3.500 Å.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and exhibits a 1D coordination network. The asymmetric unit contains one Ni(II) center, one L ligand, four coordinated water ligands and fourteen free water molecules. As shown in Fig. 2a, the Ni(II) center is six-coordinated by four water ligands plus two oxygen atoms from two independent L ligands in monodentate modes, giving a distorted octahedral geometry (Fig. 2a). The Ni–O distances are 2.026(4)–2.084(19) Å, which are comparable with previously reported data [28]. In compound 2, the deprotonated L ligands bridge two Ni atoms, each of which is bridged by two L ligands, extending the structure into a zigzag chain (Fig. 2b). The neighboring two zigzag chains are interconnected through hydrogen bonds between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO–O = 2.687–2.719 Å), to generate a 2D supramolecular network (Fig. 2c). This is connected into three dimensions by another hydrogen bond interaction between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO–O = 2.692 Å, Fig. 2d). The 1D channels along the crystallographic b-axis are filled by free water molecules; the pore size is ca. 9.6 × 11.5 Å2 (Fig. 2d, taking into account of the van der Waals radii, measured as the largest and shortest distances between the diagonals of the parallelogram). The PLATON calculations show that the guest accessible volume (1710.2 Å3 per unit cell) comprises 42.7% of the unit cell volume [26].

Crystal structure of compound 2

Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and exhibits a 1D coordination network. The asymmetric unit contains one Ni(II) center, one L ligand, four coordinated water ligands and fourteen free water molecules. As shown in Fig. 2a, the Ni(II) center is six-coordinated by four water ligands plus two oxygen atoms from two independent L ligands in monodentate modes, giving a distorted octahedral geometry (Fig. 2a). The Ni-O distances are 2.026(4)-2.084(19) Å, which are comparable with previously reported data [28]. In compound 2, the deprotonated L ligands bridge two Ni atoms, each of which is bridged by two L ligands, extending the structure into a zigzag chain (Fig. 2b). The neighboring two zigzag chains are interconnected through hydrogen bonds between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO-O = 2.687-2.719 Å), to generate a 2D supramolecular network (Fig. 2c). This is connected into three dimensions by another hydrogen bond interaction between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO-O = 2.692 Å, Fig. 2d). The 1D channels along the crystallographic b-axis are filled by free water molecules; the pore size is ca. 9.6 × 11.5 Å2 (Fig. 2d, taking into account of the van der Waals radii, measured as the largest and shortest distances between the diagonals of the parallelogram). The PLATON calculations show that the guest accessible volume (1710.2 Å3 per unit cell) comprises 42.7% of the unit cell volume [26].

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analyses were performed under an N2 atmosphere on crystalline samples of both compounds (Figure S3-S4). For compound 1, the first weight loss occurred at 50–110 °C, corresponding to loss of the free solvent molecules (calc. 12.8%, obs. 12.5%). The next weight loss occurred (calc. 4.8%, obs. 4.6%) from 110 to 200 °C, which could be attributed to the loss of two coordinated water ligands. Above ca. 300 °C, compound 1 started to lose its ligand L as a result of thermal decomposition. In compound 2, the loss of the free water molecules (calc. 28.9%, obs. 28.5%) occurred from 30 to 145 °C. The next process occurred at 145–200 °C with a weight loss of 8.3% (calc. 8.5%), corresponding to loss of four coordinated water ligands. Then above ca. 300 °C, compound 2 started to decompose.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analyses

The thermogravimetric analyses were performed under an N2 atmosphere on crystalline samples of both compounds (Figure S3-S4). For compound 1, the first weight loss occurred at 50-110 °C, corresponding to loss of the free solvent molecules (calc. 12.8%, obs. 12.5%). The next weight loss occurred (calc. 4.8%, obs. 4.6%) from 110 to 200 °C, which could be attributed to the loss of two coordinated water ligands. Above ca. 300 °C, compound 1 started to lose its ligand L as a result of thermal decomposition. In compound 2, the loss of the free water molecules (calc. 28.9%, obs. 28.5%) occurred from 30 to 145 °C. The next process occurred at 145-200 °C with a weight loss of 8.3% (calc. 8.5%), corresponding to loss of four coordinated water ligands. Then above ca. 300 °C, compound 2 started to decompose.

elements.content: Both compounds show color changes upon illumination with a 300 W Xe lamp (Fig. 3). The yellow samples of both compounds turn dark green or green after illumination. The green photoproducts are stable in air without any noticeable color change for two days, but the color slowly changes back to yellow upon prolonged standing in air. In addition, such decolored samples also display color changes after further irradiation, indicating reversible photochromism for both compounds. The UV–Vis reflectance spectra were measured before and after illumination. The original spectra both show strong absorption bands below 400 nm, with rapidly decreased tailing in the visible light region, assigned to the n–π* and π–π* transitions of the conjugated aromatic carboxylate. The photoproducts of both compounds show new characteristic bands at 520 and 690 nm. These bands are similar to those observed for the bipyridinium radical [29, 30], suggesting that the color change of may arise from the photoinduced generation of radicals in the ligand L. Their coloration tends to be saturated after illumination for 30 min, as the UV–Vis spectra show no further change, indicating that the photochromic process has gone to completion.
elements.clean_text:
Photochromic properties

Both compounds show color changes upon illumination with a 300 W Xe lamp (Fig. 3). The yellow samples of both compounds turn dark green or green after illumination. The green photoproducts are stable in air without any noticeable color change for two days, but the color slowly changes back to yellow upon prolonged standing in air. In addition, such decolored samples also display color changes after further irradiation, indicating reversible photochromism for both compounds. The UV-Vis reflectance spectra were measured before and after illumination. The original spectra both show strong absorption bands below 400 nm, with rapidly decreased tailing in the visible light region, assigned to the n-π* and π-π* transitions of the conjugated aromatic carboxylate. The photoproducts of both compounds show new characteristic bands at 520 and 690 nm. These bands are similar to those observed for the bipyridinium radical [29, 30], suggesting that the color change of may arise from the photoinduced generation of radicals in the ligand L. Their coloration tends to be saturated after illumination for 30 min, as the UV-Vis spectra show no further change, indicating that the photochromic process has gone to completion.

elements.content: To confirm the generation of the radicals, the electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra of both compounds were measured before and after irradiation (Fig. 4). The ESR spectrum of the virgin sample 1 is broad, which is typical of a normal Mn(II) complex [23, 31]. However, a signal was observed at g = 2.0023, which is uncertain whether the signal has a contribution from residual radicals. After irradiation, the signal at g = 2.0023 is dramatically increased in intensity, confirming the formation of radicals (Fig. 4a). For compound 2, no organic radical signals were detected before irradiation [32]; however, after light irradiation, a noticeable signal with a g value of 2.0042 was observed, suggesting the generation of viologen radicals (Fig. 4b). It is generally known that viologen derivatives are redox active and can generate radicals upon light irradiation. The PXRD and IR spectra of these compounds show no obvious changes during the photochromic process, suggesting that the crystal structure remains intact (Figure S1-S2 and S5-S6). Thus, the photochromic process may be attributed to photoinduced radical generation within the viologen ligand.

elements.content: Magnetic studies have been performed on powdered crystalline samples of both compounds before and after irradiation. The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 1–2 were investigated in the range of 2–300 K with a 1 kOe applied field (Fig. 5). The χMT of 1 at 300 K before irradiation is 4.11 cm3 K mol−1, which is slightly lower than the value for one magnetically non-interacting Mn2+ ion with S = 5/2 and g = 2 (χMT = 4.375 cm3 K mol−1). With decreasing temperature, the χMT value increases and reaches 7.38 cm3 K mol−1 at 2.0 K. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility in the temperature range 2-300 K is well fitted by the Curie–Weiss law with C = 3.92 cm3 K mol−1 and θ = 8.10 K (Figure S7), indicating ferromagnetic coupling between the Mn centers. After illumination with Xe light for 30 min, the χMT value at 300 K fell by 11.4%. This reduction is larger than that previously reported by Iversen et al. [33].
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties

Magnetic studies have been performed on powdered crystalline samples of both compounds before and after irradiation. The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 1-2 were investigated in the range of 2-300 K with a 1 kOe applied field (Fig. 5). The χMT of 1 at 300 K before irradiation is 4.11 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly lower than the value for one magnetically non-interacting Mn2+ ion with S = 5/2 and g = 2 (χMT = 4.375 cm3 K mol-1). With decreasing temperature, the χMT value increases and reaches 7.38 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility in the temperature range 2-300 K is well fitted by the Curie-Weiss law with C = 3.92 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = 8.10 K (Figure S7), indicating ferromagnetic coupling between the Mn centers. After illumination with Xe light for 30 min, the χMT value at 300 K fell by 11.4%. This reduction is larger than that previously reported by Iversen et al. [33].

elements.content: χMT versus temperature (T) for 1 (a) and 2 (b) before and after irradiation at 1 kOe
elements.clean_text: Fig. 5χMT versus temperature (T) for 1 (a) and 2 (b) before and after irradiation at 1 kOe

elements.content: For compound 2, the value of χMT at 300 K is 1.37 cm3 K mol−1, as expected for the spin-only value of one Ni2+ with S = 1 and g = 2.31. As the temperature decreases, the χMT value remains almost constant down to about 50 K and then starts to increase rapidly, reaching 3.05 cm3 K mol−1 at 14 K, after which it drops abruptly to a minimum value of 1.28 cm3 K mol−1 at 2 K. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities obeys the Curie–Weiss law above 5 K with C = 1.40 cm3 K mol−1 and θ = 8.53 K (Figure S8), consistent with ferromagnetic coupling between the Ni2+ centers. After illumination with Xe light for 30 min, the χMT value at 300 K fell by 10.5%. The observed decreases in χMT at 300 K for both compounds after illumination may be attributed to the strong interaction between the viologen radical and the metal ions (Mn2+/Ni2+). The magnetic behavior will require more detailed study in the future.

elements.content: In conclusion, two new coordination polymers were solvothermally synthesized by using a rigid viologen-based ligand. Both compounds display prominent photochromic and photomagnetic behavior upon light irradiation. Hence, this work demonstrates a new strategy for the design of molecular photomagnetic materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, two new coordination polymers were solvothermally synthesized by using a rigid viologen-based ligand. Both compounds display prominent photochromic and photomagnetic behavior upon light irradiation. Hence, this work demonstrates a new strategy for the design of molecular photomagnetic materials.

[H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and MnCl2·4H2O (0.020 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL), and the mixture was stirred for 10 min. Then, dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 72 h in a sealed glass bottle. The yellow crystals were separated by filtration, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 68%. Anal. Calcd for C26H18MnN2O10: C, 54.41; N, 4.88; H, 3.14. Found, C, 54.32; N, 4.54; H, 3.08. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3472(br), 3113(w), 3010(m), 1671(m), 1619(s), 1562(s), 1536(m), 1395(s), 1338(s), 1173(m), 1068(m), 923(m), 757(m), 689(s), 507(m).

Synthesis of compound <bold>2</bold>

[H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and NiCl2·6H2O (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL) and stirred for 10 min. Dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was then added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 48 h in a sealed glass bottle. The light yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 73%. Anal. Calcd for C26H50N2NiO26: C, 36.05; N, 3.24; H, 5.78. Found, C, 36.23; N, 3.32; H, 5.65. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3229(br), 3110(w), 3060(w), 1648(m), 1613(s), 1550(s), 1471(m), 1347(s), 1211(s), 1073(m), 826(m), 727(s), 582(m).

Synthesis of compound 1

[H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and MnCl2⋅4H2O (0.020 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL), and the mixture was stirred for 10 min. Then, dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 72 h in a sealed glass bottle. The yellow crystals were separated by filtration, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 68%. Anal. Calcd for C26H18MnN2O10: C, 54.41; N, 4.88; H, 3.14. Found, C, 54.32; N, 4.54; H, 3.08. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3472(br), 3113(w), 3010(m), 1671(m), 1619(s), 1562(s), 1536(m), 1395(s), 1338(s), 1173(m), 1068(m), 923(m), 757(m), 689(s), 507(m).

Synthesis of compound 2

[H4L]Cl2 (0.006 g, 0.01 mmol) and NiCl2⋅6H2O (0.024 g, 0.10 mmol) were mixed in H2O/MeOH/EtOH (3:0.5:0.5 v/v 4 mL) and stirred for 10 min. Dicyandiamide (0.168 g, 2 mmol) was then added with stirring. The resulting suspension was kept at 100 °C for 48 h in a sealed glass bottle. The light yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed several times with H2O and dried in air. Yield: 73%. Anal. Calcd for C26H50N2NiO26: C, 36.05; N, 3.24; H, 5.78. Found, C, 36.23; N, 3.32; H, 5.65. IR data (KBr, cm-1): 3229(br), 3110(w), 3060(w), 1648(m), 1613(s), 1550(s), 1471(m), 1347(s), 1211(s), 1073(m), 826(m), 727(s), 582(m).

cln_elements.content:
Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n and exhibits a 1D coordination network. The asymmetric unit contains one Ni(II) center, one L ligand, four coordinated water ligands and fourteen free water molecules. As shown in Fig. 2a, the Ni(II) center is six-coordinated by four water ligands plus two oxygen atoms from two independent L ligands in monodentate modes, giving a distorted octahedral geometry (Fig. 2a). The Ni–O distances are 2.026(4)–2.084(19) Å, which are comparable with previously reported data [28]. In compound 2, the deprotonated L ligands bridge two Ni atoms, each of which is bridged by two L ligands, extending the structure into a zigzag chain (Fig. 2b). The neighboring two zigzag chains are interconnected through hydrogen bonds between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO–O = 2.687–2.719 Å), to generate a 2D supramolecular network (Fig. 2c). This is connected into three dimensions by another hydrogen bond interaction between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO–O = 2.692 Å, Fig. 2d). The 1D channels along the crystallographic b-axis are filled by free water molecules; the pore size is ca. 9.6 × 11.5 Å2 (Fig. 2d, taking into account of the van der Waals radii, measured as the largest and shortest distances between the diagonals of the parallelogram). The PLATON calculations show that the guest accessible volume (1710.2 Å3 per unit cell) comprises 42.7% of the unit cell volume [26].

Thermogravimetric analyses

The thermogravimetric analyses were performed under an N2 atmosphere on crystalline samples of both compounds (Figure S3-S4). For compound 1, the first weight loss occurred at 50–110 °C, corresponding to loss of the free solvent molecules (calc. 12.8%, obs. 12.5%). The next weight loss occurred (calc. 4.8%, obs. 4.6%) from 110 to 200 °C, which could be attributed to the loss of two coordinated water ligands. Above ca. 300 °C, compound 1 started to lose its ligand L as a result of thermal decomposition. In compound 2, the loss of the free water molecules (calc. 28.9%, obs. 28.5%) occurred from 30 to 145 °C. The next process occurred at 145–200 °C with a weight loss of 8.3% (calc. 8.5%), corresponding to loss of four coordinated water ligands. Then above ca. 300 °C, compound 2 started to decompose.

Magnetic properties

Magnetic studies have been performed on powdered crystalline samples of both compounds before and after irradiation. The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 1–2 were investigated in the range of 2–300 K with a 1 kOe applied field (Fig. 5). The χMT of 1 at 300 K before irradiation is 4.11 cm3 K mol−1, which is slightly lower than the value for one magnetically non-interacting Mn2+ ion with S = 5/2 and g = 2 (χMT = 4.375 cm3 K mol−1). With decreasing temperature, the χMT value increases and reaches 7.38 cm3 K mol−1 at 2.0 K. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility in the temperature range 2-300 K is well fitted by the Curie–Weiss law with C = 3.92 cm3 K mol−1 and θ = 8.10 K (Figure S7), indicating ferromagnetic coupling between the Mn centers. After illumination with Xe light for 30 min, the χMT value at 300 K fell by 11.4%. This reduction is larger than that previously reported by Iversen et al. [33].

For compound 2, the value of χMT at 300 K is 1.37 cm3 K mol−1, as expected for the spin-only value of one Ni2+ with S = 1 and g = 2.31. As the temperature decreases, the χMT value remains almost constant down to about 50 K and then starts to increase rapidly, reaching 3.05 cm3 K mol−1 at 14 K, after which it drops abruptly to a minimum value of 1.28 cm3 K mol−1 at 2 K. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities obeys the Curie–Weiss law above 5 K with C = 1.40 cm3 K mol−1 and θ = 8.53 K (Figure S8), consistent with ferromagnetic coupling between the Ni2+ centers. After illumination with Xe light for 30 min, the χMT value at 300 K fell by 10.5%. The observed decreases in χMT at 300 K for both compounds after illumination may be attributed to the strong interaction between the viologen radical and the metal ions (Mn2+/Ni2+). The magnetic behavior will require more detailed study in the future.

Crystal structure of compound 2

The neighboring two zigzag chains are interconnected through hydrogen bonds between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO-O = 2.687-2.719 Å), to generate a 2D supramolecular network (Fig. 2c). This is connected into three dimensions by another hydrogen bond interaction between the water ligands and uncoordinated carboxyl groups of the organic ligands (dO-O = 2.692 Å, Fig. 2d). The thermogravimetric analyses were performed under an N2 atmosphere on crystalline samples of both compounds (Figure S3-S4). In compound 2, the loss of the free water molecules (calc. 28.9%, obs. 28.5%) occurred from 30 to 145 °C. The next process occurred at 145-200 °C with a weight loss of 8.3% (calc. 8.5%), corresponding to loss of four coordinated water ligands. Then above ca. 300 °C, compound 2 started to decompose.

Magnetic studies have been performed on powdered crystalline samples of both compounds before and after irradiation. The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 1-2 were investigated in the range of 2-300 K with a 1 kOe applied field (Fig. 5). The χMT of 1 at 300 K before irradiation is 4.11 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly lower than the value for one magnetically non-interacting Mn2+ ion with S = 5/2 and g = 2 (χMT = 4.375 cm3 K mol-1). With decreasing temperature, the χMT value increases and reaches 7.38 cm3 K mol-1 at 2.0 K. After illumination with Xe light for 30 min, the χMT value at 300 K fell by 11.4%. This reduction is larger than that previously reported by Iversen et al. [33].

The observed decreases in χMT at 300 K for both compounds after illumination may be attributed to the strong interaction between the viologen radical and the metal ions (Mn2+/Ni2+). The magnetic behavior will require more detailed study in the future.
